awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mesoscopic Defect Field Interactions in Materials with High Number Density of Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Deformation behavior of crystalline materials is highly complex, owing to a hierarchy of length scales that describes their structural makeup. Interfaces link distinct crystal structures or material phases at these various length scales. The interactions of crystalline defects with interfaces are chiefly responsible for the emergent material behavior at the application scale. The collective interactions of defects and interfaces through multiple scales up to the higher scale of everyday applications have been extremely challenging to resolve experimentally and have also not been captured using computer simulations to the desired sophistication. This is a significant obstacle to the understanding of the behavior of complex materials, where high density of specific interfaces is instrumental in achieving superior functional and/or mechanical properties. This research aims to address this challenge through the study of superlattices and metamaterials by exploiting and further advancing an atomistic-to-continuum scale method. It is expected that this research will significantly promote the fields of mechanics of materials and computational materials science, with commensurate impact on the rapidly developing field of computational materials design, which will advance national health, prosperity, and welfare. This work is also expected to have substantial broader impact through training of undergraduate students in high-performance computing, graduate curriculum enhancements, and dissemination of codes to the wider community. The project will also reach out to engage students from underrepresented groups.

Superlattices and metamaterials represent two emerging material systems that derive their exceptional properties from structure rather than composition. With their well-ordered periodic interfaces and structure, superlattices and metamaterials provide model systems amenable to systematic study of the collective role of interfaces on evolving defect structures. The goal of this collaborative effort is to demonstrate the collective role of interfaces and defects on mechanical properties by studying this special class of material systems by using an advanced Concurrent Atomistic-Continuum (CAC) approach. It is expected that this research will identify the dominant deformation mechanisms as well as the key structural variables that control the materials behavior and the underlying mechanisms, explore the critical length scale or structural parameters at which the materials exhibit a transition from ductile to brittle behavior, and investigate the fundamental phenomena that control the plastic flow and fracture behaviors in these material systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research was to demonstrate the collective role of interfaces and defects on mechanical properties in metallic multilayers, superlattices and metamaterials. Our long-term vision is to achieve comprehensive predictive understanding and methods to facilitate design of new materials with a high density of interfaces. 

Significant outcomes of this joint Georgia Tech-University of Florida project are as follows:

  • New knowledge and valuable data were developed for defect structures, wave dynamics and failure patterns, as well as the underlying mechanisms, in multilayers, superlattices and metamaterials.
  • Reformulated the CAC conservation equations to enable atomic-scale field representation of transport processes, enabling a mathematically rigorous solution to highly nonequilibrium transport problems.
  • Collaborated in development of a massively parallel algorithm, which enables CAC to become one of the first open-sourced methods to successfully solve a system with O(N/P) scaling when the solution involves multiple scales of finite elements, discrete particles, and their interaction through non-local forces.
  • Collaborated to implement the CAC formulation in the LAMMPS codebase, which makes CAC to be broadly and easily accessible to the broad worldwide computational materials science and mechanics communities. 
  • Used CAC to study evolution of misfit dislocation structures within semi-coherent interfaces ahead of incoming dislocation pileups for both Ni/Cu and Cu/Ag bicrystals/multilayers. 
  • Used CAC to study slip transmission of dislocations across semi-coherent interfaces in both Ni/Cu and Cu/Ag bilayers and conditions that promote threading dislocations.
  • Identified the type, density, and structure of defect structures associated with PbTe/PbSe, Si/Ge, GaN/AlN phase interfaces, and their role in mechanical and thermal transport properties of the heterostructures, adding mechanistic understanding and valuable data about the defect structure and dynamics in various semiconductor multilayers.
  • Reproduced the failure patterns of Si micropillars under compression that has been observed in experiments and identified the mechanism for the formation of the central crack as a result of dislocations piling ups and intersection of slip bands.
  • Obtained, for the first time, the multiscale details of the transient processes of phonon scattering and transmission in Si phononic crystals, providing a clear picture of the nature of phonon transport and its dependence on the structural parameters of the phononic crystals, thereby making an important step forward in establishing a fundamental understanding of wave dynamics in periodically structured metamaterials.  
  • illustrated and quantified two mechanisms for phonon-dislocation interaction: (1) phonon scattering by the strain field of stationary dislocations, and (2) phonon scattering by dislocations that vibrate via the local modes of the dislocations; the latter, leads to resonant phonon-dislocation interaction, which is manifested as local maxima of out-of-phase vibration of the atoms on the two sides of the slip plane, leading to local minima of the energy transmission in the heterostructure that contains one interface. This work has also demonstrated, for the first time, the collective motion of dislocations in dislocation networks under ultrafast phonon pulses.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2022
Modified by: David L Mcdowell

The goal of this research was to demonstrate the collective role of interfaces and defects on mechanical properties in metallic multilayers, superlattices and metamaterials. Our long-term vision is to achieve comprehensive predictive understanding and methods to facilitate design of new materials with a high density of interfaces. 

Significant outcomes of this joint Georgia Tech-University of Florida project are as follows:

New knowledge and valuable data were developed for defect structures, wave dynamics and failure patterns, as well as the underlying mechanisms, in multilayers, superlattices and metamaterials.
Reformulated the CAC conservation equations to enable atomic-scale field representation of transport processes, enabling a mathematically rigorous solution to highly nonequilibrium transport problems. 
Collaborated in development of a massively parallel algorithm, which enables CAC to become one of the first open-sourced methods to successfully solve a system with O(N/P) scaling when the solution involves multiple scales of finite elements, discrete particles, and their interaction through non-local forces.
Collaborated to implement the CAC formulation in the LAMMPS codebase, which makes CAC to be broadly and easily accessible to the broad worldwide computational materials science and mechanics communities.  
Used CAC to study evolution of misfit dislocation structures within semi-coherent interfaces ahead of incoming dislocation pileups for both Ni/Cu and Cu/Ag bicrystals/multilayers. 
Used CAC to study slip transmission of dislocations across semi-coherent interfaces in both Ni/Cu and Cu/Ag bilayers and conditions that promote threading dislocations. 
Identified the type, density, and structure of defect structures associated with PbTe/PbSe, Si/Ge, GaN/AlN phase interfaces, and their role in mechanical and thermal transport properties of the heterostructures, adding mechanistic understanding and valuable data about the defect structure and dynamics in various semiconductor multilayers.
Reproduced the failure patterns of Si micropillars under compression that has been observed in experiments and identified the mechanism for the formation of the central crack as a result of dislocations piling ups and intersection of slip bands.
Obtained, for the first time, the multiscale details of the transient processes of phonon scattering and transmission in Si phononic crystals, providing a clear picture of the nature of phonon transport and its dependence on the structural parameters of the phononic crystals, thereby making an important step forward in establishing a fundamental understanding of wave dynamics in periodically structured metamaterials.  
illustrated and quantified two mechanisms for phonon-dislocation interaction: (1) phonon scattering by the strain field of stationary dislocations, and (2) phonon scattering by dislocations that vibrate via the local modes of the dislocations; the latter, leads to resonant phonon-dislocation interaction, which is manifested as local maxima of out-of-phase vibration of the atoms on the two sides of the slip plane, leading to local minima of the energy transmission in the heterostructure that contains one interface. This work has also demonstrated, for the first time, the collective motion of dislocations in dislocation networks under ultrafast phonon pulses.
